htmlContent:
JWT Authentication

JWT (JSON Web Token) is a secure method for transmitting information between clients and servers as a JSON object. It ensures authentication, authorization, and secure data exchange for modern web applications.

Key Features

  • Token-based authentication for stateless servers
  • Stateless sessions that scale efficiently
  • Securely store user data in tokens
  • Integrates easily with REST APIs and microservices

Best Practices

  • Use HTTPS to transmit tokens securely
  • Keep tokens short-lived and refresh periodically
  • Store refresh tokens securely (httpOnly cookies or secure storage)
  • Validate tokens on every request to protect APIs
  • Handle token expiration gracefully with proper error messages
"JWT enables secure, stateless authentication for web applications, making it easier to scale and maintain APIs."

Example Usage

import jwt from 'jsonwebtoken';

const payload = { userId: 123 };
const secret = process.env.JWT_SECRET;
const token = jwt.sign(payload, secret, { expiresIn: '1h' });

// Verify token
try {
  const decoded = jwt.verify(token, secret);
  console.log(decoded);
} catch (err) {
  console.error('Invalid or expired token');
}

Next Steps

  • Integrate JWT with your Express.js backend for secure routes
  • Use middleware to protect API endpoints
  • Implement role-based authorization for users
  • Combine JWT with OAuth2 or third-party auth providers for added security
  • Monitor token usage and refresh cycles for optimal performance

By following these JWT practices, you can build secure, maintainable, and scalable web applications with reliable authentication and authorization mechanisms.
